Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Algorithms for Matching, Auction, and Scheduling Problems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research addresses the design and analysis of efficient algorithms for bipartite matching problems. Weighted and unweighted problems are investigated, as well as stable matching variants based on ordinal preferences. Dynamic variants are also considered; here the goal is to rapidly update an optimal solution when a small change is made to the input.

There is an intimate connection between weighted bipartite matching and a class of combinatorial auctions known as unit-demand auctions. For example, one fundamental approach to the problem of allocating and pricing items in a sealed-bid unit-demand auction involves computing a maximum-weight matching in a corresponding bipartite graph. This project addresses the design and analysis of unit-demand auctions with multiple rounds of bidding. Such "dynamic" auctions are substantially more difficult to analyze than their sealed-bid counterparts, but offer important practical advantages.

Certain scheduling problems are also closely related to bipartite matching. This project addresses the design and analysis of algorithms for scheduling-related variants of bipartite matching problems.

In spite of decades of research on combinatorial auctions, the predominant auction format available to the general public for auctioning consumer goods remains the single-item dynamic second-price format, as popularized by eBay. This research addresses the design of a scalable infrastructure for supporting the more expressive class of dynamic unit-demand auctions. The key potential benefit of such an infrastructure is enhanced economic efficiency, that is, improved matching of auction items to the bidders who value them the most. Such enhanced efficiency offers direct benefits to society. In addition, the matching and scheduling problems addressed in this project are fundamental in nature and have numerous practical applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In certain real-world applications, we are given a set of indivisible items and a set of agents who are each interested in acquiring at most one of these items, and we need to determine how to allocate the items to the agents. Three different classes of such "matching problems" have been studied in this project.

The first class is concerned with using an auction mechanism to determine a winning bidder and a selling price for each item.  With respect to this class, we have studied a variety of models in which a bidder specifies only two or three numerical values, which are are used to determine a separate bid for each item in an arbitrarily large set. For such models, we can hope to make bidding more convenient in certain applications, and to provide much faster algorithms for determining pricing and allocation. Along these lines, we have obtained faster algorithms for vertex-weighted matching in convex bipartite graphs and two-directional orthogonal ray graphs.  We have also introduced the problem of edge-weighted matching with linear edge weights, for which we have obtained a fast algorithm.  We have presented an even faster algorithm for a restricted version of this problem that corresponds to a classic scheduling problem for unit-time jobs.

The second class addresses settings in which it is inappropriate to allow money to play a role in determining the allocation. For example, consider the kidney exchange problem, in which the "items" are kidneys available for donation, and the "agents" are individuals in need of a kidney transplant; here, instead of allocating the kidneys to the highest bidders, we would like to optimize medical outcomes.  In this project, we have contributed to a recent line of research generalizing the classic housing markets model of Shapley and Scarf. In this model, there are an equal number of agents and items, each agent owns a distinct item and has ordinal preferences over the entire set of items, and the goal is to reallocate the items to better reflect the preferences of the agents. For the case where preferences are strict, Shapley and Scarf presented the elegant top trading cycles (TTC) algorithm and showed that it produces the unique allocation enjoying a number of desirable game-theoretic properties. A recent line of research is concerned with generalizing these classic results to the case where the agent preferences are allowed to include ties. For example, in kidney exchange, it may be that several donor kidneys are equally suitable for a given recipient.  In this project, we have developed a fast implementation for a generalization of the TTC algorithm that allows ties in the preferences. Like TTC, our algorithm is strategyproof for the agents, meaning that no agent can benefit by lying about their preferences.

The third class is a variant of the second class in which the "items" correspond to a second category of agents.  In this variant, the agents in each category have preferences over the agents in the other category. For example, matching problems of this sort arise in applications to online dating and school choice. This project has made two main contributions in this area, both of which are related to the classic stable marriage model of Gale and Shapley. In the most basic version of this model, we have an equal number of agents on both sides of the market, and we wish to determine a "stable" matching that pairs up all of the agents. The famous deferred acceptance (DA) algorithm of Gale and Shapley is guaranteed to compute a stable matching. In this project, we showed how to generalize the DA algorithm to obtain a "Pareto-stable" matching when the agent preferences are allowed to include ties.  Like the DA algorithm, our algorithm is "group strategyproof" for the agents on one side of the market, which means that no coalition of the agents on that side can all gain by jointly lying about their preferences.  Our second main contribution is concerned with the problem of stable marriage where preference lists may be "incomplete" (i.e., an agent can refuse to be matched to certain agents on the other side of the market), and where agents on one side of the market are allowed to have ties in their preferences. For this version of the stable marriage problem, stable matchings can differ in cardinality, motivating the problem of computing a max-cardinality stable matching.  This optimization problem is known to be NP-hard, so researchers have focused on the design of approximation algorithms.  We have presented a generalization of the DA algorithm that achieves a significantly improved approximation ratio for this problem.
